Royal Warehouses.text: A complex of several large warehouses where everything from resources to documents, and confiscated contraband is stored. These huge storages are kept under close surveillance by the Royal Swords, and access to any of them is granted only with an official letter of authorization.

King's Forge.name: King's Forge
King's Forge.text:
The royal smithy is where everything from metalware to gears of war is crafted when the crown requires it. The official coins of the realm are also minted here. The smithy is known for its towering chimneys and hallways painted orange by the light of the dwarven’ forges. It is a well-guarded location with many soldiers stationed around the premises.

The most imposing figure in the swarm of crafters and workers is Somrin “Fernidad” Ironhammer, an imposing giant of a dwarf who is over eight feet tall.

Somrin is a barbarian shaman from the edges of the Mountainfalls, a strange and abandoned land of endless mountain peaks, who crafts the most reliable weapons.

Reference:

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.PldFtmYx15BRagkN.JournalEntryPage.5Gt0b2U2GOdeonxt#dancing-with-giants]{Dancing with Giants} (Introductory Adventure)

House of the Soldiers.name: House of the Soldiers
House of the Soldiers.text:
These are the barracks of the @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.iiOhibBiYRG3FzPK#royal-army]{Royal Army}, the soldiers of Aglarion. It comprises a walled compound of six long, two-story buildings and a simple large service building of bricks with a slight greenish hue.

The single gate is always well-guarded, and the location is usually clamorous with the sounds of physical training and shouting.

A regular face at the gate is Jacob Hammersmyth, a lazy and cynical old warrior who worked his way into a position of stamping entry and release documents.

He seems like a weak-willed fellow who could easily be fooled, but in reality, he is a fiercely loyal and meticulously observant servant of the crown.

Reference:

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.GUVYl3sAqhC1ZZtI.JournalEntryPage.ZOPkaJIb1KcUOw1k#the-nimble-eagle]{The Nimble Eagle} (Competition during the King's games, chapter 1)

Karramosa Villa.name: Karramosa Villa
Karramosa Villa.text:
This imposing villa is surrounded by beautiful gardens that speak of wealth.

The gratuitously decorated structure is striking amidst its surroundings, including beautiful stables and carriage sheds. The stone pillars of the main gate are decorated with small semi-precious stones that are deeply embedded. However, some of them have been skillfully picked before the gate guards could prevent the thefts.

As people call it, the Starry Gate flickers in the night as the light of the moon shines upon it.

References:

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.y73fauf7VCxVrzTe#house-karramosa]{House Karramosa} (Noble house)

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.bhFFbrHi0j5J8Xgg.JournalEntryPage.M8HPVyOMV9ZwAAI8]{Monastery of Past Lives} (Kingdom of Aglarion location 10)

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.PldFtmYx15BRagkN.JournalEntryPage.C5tAJjrsRKymhAU8#ire-of-the-ringmaidens]{Ire of the Ringmaidens} (Introductory adventure)

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.MJu1mw3t3CuynD5j.JournalEntryPage.20GpONvl0ezZShHU#greedy-retributions]{Greedy Retributions} (Cursed Coronation event, chapter 2)

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.Nq3FpTKjZRMBlD6Z.JournalEntryPage.5lrheTIyFtYevxdO]{Monastery of Past Lives} (Cursed kingdom of Aglarion, location 10)

Rose Garden Park.name: Rose Garden Park
Rose Garden Park.text:
Bordered by beautiful villas, this park is home to many varieties of roses of all colors and sizes, making it a favorite place for romantic getaways.

A few years back, a serial killer was hunting for couples in the park, leaving them in macabre displays. @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.iiOhibBiYRG3FzPK#red-cloak-lawgivers]{Red Cloak Lawgivers} locked the culprit in the @UUID[.Jx1Y72KiuljK87PO]{Dungeon of Tears}.

Some still fear entering the park after dark, and there are always two Royal Swords on patrol.

The person arrested was not the real killer, as he was possessed by a vengefull ghost.

Reference:

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.PldFtmYx15BRagkN.JournalEntryPage.C5tAJjrsRKymhAU8#ire-of-the-ringmaidens]{Ire of the Ringmaidens} (Introductory adventure)

Tomb of the First King.name: Tomb of the First King
Tomb of the First King.text:
Within this gated building in the Royal Court is the resting place of @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.xlCqGIMNmyhjubvz#the-melkar-dynasty-(year-0–142)]{King Razmyrel Valsyr Melkar I}.

It is a ten feet high unworked block of granite onto which his friend and ally, Master Arlen the Constructor, molded the king’s perfect likeness with the use of magic.

Engraved on the surface of the imposing rock is a single line that says, “Order is our solid foundation.” The letters are hard to make out, as it is a custom to touch the engraving for good luck so the stone has smoothed out over hundreds of years from the hands of countless visitors.

Bastion of the Knights.name: Bastion of the Knights
Bastion of the Knights.text:
This large building in the Royal Court accommodates the @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.iiOhibBiYRG3FzPK#knights-of-the-crown]{Knights of the Crown} and serves as their living quarters and training halls. A broad stairway leads to an ornate stone gate that encloses a somewhat dimly lit interior with narrow corridors and small cells. A fencing hall and a chapel are located on the ground floor, while the dining hall and private cells are on the following two levels of the building.

Crownwarden @UUID[Actor.4lfK5fVzgeQVo8n7]{Lord Cyne Monder} spends most of his time with his knights at this location rather than at his ancestral villa in the High District.

Royal Court.name: Royal Court
Royal Court.text:
The Royal Court is located on a large walled island that incorporates the Royal Palace, @UUID[.EY998Ndw2eeoAWIZ]{Bastion of the Knights,} and @UUID[.dLPrvy3kleHmYSQp]{Tomb of the First King}.

The Palace includes such notable areas as the Royal Quarters, Mausoleum, Throne Room, Guest Quarters, and the Royal Treasury.

It is a closely guarded complex where the royal family and its servants, guards, assistants, and advisors live their daily lives under the protective watch of the Knights of the Crown.

References:

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.GUVYl3sAqhC1ZZtI.JournalEntryPage.3yuvz2EiDqkdmJIW]{Funeral of the King} (Main quest, chapter 1)

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.MJu1mw3t3CuynD5j.JournalEntryPage.20GpONvl0ezZShHU]{Cursed Coronation} (Main quest, chapter 2)

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.KmvjlXzSSBi3KCho.JournalEntryPage.lvpoYpLVw7gMXmfZ#the-royal-palace]{The Royal Palace} (Main quest, chapter 3)

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.sv64cqIJerN3UD4U]{Royal Palace} (Detailed location description, after the Queen Aphina's coronation)

  • @UUID[Scene.PEaoBWXGPzv8vHtb]{Royal Palace, -1 lvl} (Map, underground level)

  • @UUID[Scene.ybR0z3nbD2R54t2Q]{Royal Palace, 1st lvl} (Map, ground level)

King's Bridge.name: King's Bridge
King's Bridge.text: This slim, walled, and roofed bridge, designed and built using magic by Master Arlen, allows only one carriage to cross at a single time. The bridge walls are so narrow that one can’t even open the doors of a carriage in the passage, which is also dotted with arrow slits running on both sides. It is heavily guarded at all times.

Queen's Bridge.name: Queen's Bridge
Queen's Bridge.text: This narrow bridge is almost identical to the King’s Bridge, with the addition of magically movable large stone blocks at its center that can block passage on the bridge if needed

Wyltammer Villa.name: Wyltammer Villa
Wyltammer Villa.text:
The ancient and continuously renovated villa of the @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.y73fauf7VCxVrzTe#house-wyltammer]{Wyltammer} family displays the elegance and subtlety of elven designs. Intricate ornaments extrude from seemingly natural surfaces as if the building was grown organically rather than built. Its large garden and the greenhouse that occupies its center are perfectly kept. The glass greenhouse features exotic flowers and some rare birds, harmless insects, and small rodents, which are usually found near elven settlements.

The family’s assistant, Xela Stormfane, is a kind and warmhearted chubby human lady who graduated from the @UUID[.76KqRw9Y32UCdzY1]{College of Minstrels} (location 25).

Xela Stormfane is writing a lengthy poetic novel about angels in love with mortals, and has absolutely no idea about the secrets of her masters but knows a lot about their everyday activities and assets.

Reference:

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.y73fauf7VCxVrzTe#house-wyltammer]{House Wyltammer} (Noble house)

Temple of Knowledge.name: Temple of Knowledge
Temple of Knowledge.text:
A once majestic, now neglected temple that serves as a public library is currently run by Father Golvin, a young half-blue dragon cleric of the Wise One from the @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.YBau4aklzXO4754W#isles-of-xantharos]{Isles of Xantharos}.

Books are available for reading at the temple and sold at almost symbolic prices.

The young cleric took over duties at the temple after the disappearance of his tutor, Father Lestor, the former head priest.

Reference:

  • The @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.RvZvrek5H1zHmg1M#knowledge]{Wise One}, god of Knowledge (Religion of the kingdom)

Domiren Villa.name: Domiren Villa
Domiren Villa.text:
The @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.y73fauf7VCxVrzTe#house-domiren]{Domiren} family villa is a once majestic building now in a state of utter neglect.

The iron-wrought front gates and fences are overgrown, as are its gardens. The previously magnificent and highly fashionable topiary bushes have become unrecognizable, twisted forms of themselves.

The few servants who can bear the family only remain in their service because of the lavish payment. As a result, visitors are rare and also of the shady type most of the time.

Reference

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.y73fauf7VCxVrzTe#house-domiren]{House Domiren} (Noble house)

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.PldFtmYx15BRagkN.JournalEntryPage.5Gt0b2U2GOdeonxt#a-shameless-party]{A Shameless Party} (Introductory adventure)

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.MJu1mw3t3CuynD5j.JournalEntryPage.20GpONvl0ezZShHU#a-noble-in-trouble]{A Noble In Trouble} (Cursed coronation event, chapter 2)

The Napping Giant.name: The Napping Giant
The Napping Giant.text:
This colossal weather-worn statue from ancient times depicts the reclining form of a greenskinned giant or a humanoid of giant size. No one is sure what form the statue depicts. It has an unidentifiable glyph on its forehead. The findings of an earlier excavation confirm that the statue has the remains of wings on its back that were broken off ages ago using chisels. This find has led historians to conclude that the statue was raised in honor of the planetar Morkiel over two thousand years ago and then toppled and dewinged by Sarath and her followers.

The site is roped off from the streets, and no one is allowed to enter except for the members of the Chamber of Royal Historians.

Andre, a serious-looking tattooed half-orc soldier, is permanently stationed at the site to ensure no one enters.

Reference:

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.GUVYl3sAqhC1ZZtI.JournalEntryPage.qvV6PyPkRP6i9tTv#bugs-under-the-giant]{Bugs under the Giant} (Malicious Treasure Hunt event during the King's games, chapter 1)

House of Clenched Fists.name: House of Clenched Fists
House of Clenched Fists.text:
Master Aurello teaches self-defense techniques to the youngsters of the South District for free. He has a few pupils who have become trained fighting monks over the years and live at their master’s house.

The school is a nicely renovated two-story building with a small courtyard at its center.

Arno's Ancient Tomes.name: Arno's Ancient Tomes
Arno's Ancient Tomes.text:
A small building with a few smaller windows is the home and store of Arno Hawkspear, a nerdy and nervous human librarian who collects rare and old tomes he offers for sale at reasonable prices.

Some of his books date back to the times of the Order of the Eternal Light, considered banned by the monarchies that followed the era.

Hall of Temerity.name: Hall of Temerity
Hall of Temerity.text:
This training hall for swordsmen is run by Temerity, an optimistic and always cheerful tiefling paladin of the god of Competence, the @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.RvZvrek5H1zHmg1M#competence]{Efficient Master}, with entirely black eyes.

Temerity takes only up to four pupils at a time, whom he trains individually during regular daily sessions.

The Furlough.name: The Furlough
The Furlough.text:
This canteen is frequented mostly by Royal Swords in their free time. The kitchen is managed by Reznek Syngris, a half-elven chef who always seems rushed and behind orders, except when in the kitchen, which is a place of organized calm.

The proprietor is always fidgeting and leaves serving to his three sons.

The Curious Calligrapher.name: The Curious Calligrapher
The Curious Calligrapher.text:
Kapushek Borontyr is a halfling scribe who creates beautifully illustrated and illuminated letters, cards, and even complete copies of books.

Only a few know that the scribe is also willing to create near perfect forgeries if the payment is large enough.

Drunnag's Oils.name: Drunnag's Oils
Drunnag's Oils.text:
Drunnag Steelarm is a dwarven retiree, who has left the managing of his oil shop to his human stepson Ozian. Both Steelarms are extremely solitary individuals who try and keep to themselves. The shop is on the bottom floor of a narrow two-story redisential building and it sells many types of natural and alchemical oils, some from the most rare of plants, animals, or substances.

Shrine of the Shining Light

This is a hidden Shrine of the Shining Light, which is visited by only a trusted handful of followers of the disdained cult of the Order of the Eternal Light.

It is run by the zealous elderly dwarven priest Drunnag Steelarm and his young human acolyte Ozian, who follow the ancient radical beliefs of the Order. The temple itself is within a normal-looking, narrow residential two-story house with a secret entrance from a back alley. Father Drunnag is a dwarf retiree with a human stepson, and the two usually try to keep to themselves in their secret worship.

Giant's Boots Tavern.name: Giant's Boots Tavern
Giant's Boots Tavern.text:
The entrance of this sturdy building is flanked by the actual iron boots of a fire giant. The establishment’s inside is also decorated with the weapons and armor of the same fire giant, supposedly killed by the owner, Zor Nafalios, an ex-mercenary from overseas who turned the giant’s enormous shield into a table in the center of the tavern.

Sitting next to it is a privilege for any guest, and empty seats are rare. Many soldiers and merchants drink here, and the tavern is usually loud with physical contests, cheers, and the occasional fistfight every night.

With a permanent seat at the shield, the meanest looking guest is the mercenary Yeetarr, a fully armed hulking gnoll with a vicious set of metal teeth.

Yeetarr is a seeker of justice despite his deadly looks and is interested only in quests involving dangerous situations and righting wrongs.

Reference:

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.GUVYl3sAqhC1ZZtI.JournalEntryPage.ZOPkaJIb1KcUOw1k#the-nimble-eagle]{The Nimble Eagle} (Competition during the King's games, chapter 1)

Ironweaver's Market.name: Ironweaver's Market
Ironweaver's Market.text: The “Metal Market,” as the locals call it, is maintained for those who sell used or mint condition household metalware, weapons, or armor. The air is constantly filled with sounds of clanking and the scraping of metal against metal, as well as the sounds of haggling and deals being struck.

Black Flag Mercenary Company.name: Black Flag Mercenary Company
Black Flag Mercenary Company.text:
This small, old building is neglected both from the outside and the inside.

The top level functions as the small home of Trazz the Cruel, who runs the @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.iiOhibBiYRG3FzPK#black-flag-mercenary-company]{mercenary company}. The storefront is decorated with weapons, shields, and the occasional trophy of some wild beasts and smaller monsters. The courtyard is a small training ground where Trazz demands his employees to train daily.

Trazz keeps an eye on his favorite mercenary, Lendra Thread, a female no-nonsense, confident airling who is always ready for a challenge to a duel. Lendra’s fiercest competition within the mercenary company, usually sent on separate missions by Trazz, is Tempest Umbermoor, a tiefling pact of the blade warlock who leads the team assigned him with no regard for its safety.

References:

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.iiOhibBiYRG3FzPK#black-flag-mercenary-company]{Black Flag Mercenary Company} (Organization in the Kingdom of Aglarion)

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.PldFtmYx15BRagkN.JournalEntryPage.C5tAJjrsRKymhAU8#house-cleaning]{House Cleaning} (Introductory adventure)

The King's Pride.name: The King's Pride
The King's Pride.text:
The extensive stables of the King’s Pride are where horses in the crown’s service are kept.

All of the horses at the stable were bred and brought in from the Royal Stud Farm from outside Onadbyr.

Odds and Ends Pawnshop.name: Odds and Ends Pawnshop
Odds and Ends Pawnshop.text:
This is a ramshackle pawn shop where some claims having seen stolen goods. There is always a personal recommendation of “rare” goods to those the owner, a rude dwarf named Gywyn Talabosh, deems worthy of his time. He can procure many things one would not expect to be available in a pawn shop.

The pawn shop the front of the local smuggling activity of the @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.iiOhibBiYRG3FzPK#golden-masks]{Golden Masks}, where they try and sell illegally obteined goods.

Grazilda's Apothecary.name: Grazilda's Apothecary
Grazilda's Apothecary.text:
Markya Marosta is a young herbalist who smiles a lot as she runs her late grandmother’s business with great skill.

She dropped out of the College of Minstrels to assist her granny and became a strong devotee of the @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.RvZvrek5H1zHmg1M#life]{Redeemer}.

Dr. Samael Volkov, a human physician, and Bweltoe, the half-giant ex-barbarian delivery man from Vordan, assists her in the day to day chores of running an apothecary.

  • Markya is able to cast lower-level curative magics, and also distills magical potions with limited availability.

  • Dr. Samael Volkov is also a studious necromancer with a blunt attitude, and who doesn’t care much for anesthetics.

  • Bweltoe is secretly in love with the musically gifted cleric.

Angels' Choir Festhall.name: Angels' Choir Festhall
Angels' Choir Festhall.text:
This large elegant, domed building is home to most of the birthdays and weddings of those who can pay the hefty price for renting the establishment.

Its large marble central hall is lavishly furnished and the servants are dressed almost as elegantly as the ones in the Royal Palace.

The catering is exquisite and highly expensive as are the rest of the services, and Raun Surefoot, the halfling proprietor of the festhall makes sure that every occasion feels uniquely special for those who attend.

Monder Villa.name: Monder Villa
Monder Villa.text:
The current Crownwarden’s villa is a simple yet robust structure. His family, which has always trained its youngest members to become part of the knighthood, lives a sheltered, simple, yet generous and socially sensitive life.

Lord Cyne Monder has no heirs and just a few housekeepers to manage the villa, whose wide strong gates are always open for those in need.

References:

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.y73fauf7VCxVrzTe#house-monder]{House Monder} (Noble house of the Kingdom of Aglarion)

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.GUVYl3sAqhC1ZZtI.JournalEntryPage.iEDHqhdojiT7T3Me]{The Couatl Feather} (Main quest, chapter 1)

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.GUVYl3sAqhC1ZZtI.JournalEntryPage.PlwNzSQY7XZfjryr]{Summons at the Old Grinder} (Main quest, chapter 1)

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.MJu1mw3t3CuynD5j.JournalEntryPage.nmL6tLVj1ZvXBUUX]{The Hidden Vault of House Monder} (Main quest, chapter 2)

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.dk4TS9ooW5qSL16h]{Crypts of House Monder} (Map of the Vaults of House Monder, chapter 3)

Royal Gardens.name: Royal Gardens
Royal Gardens.text:
These beautifully kept gardens are open to the public but are always closely monitored by the Caretakers of Life and soldiers stationed here.

The park was built over the ruins of the Cathedral of the Sun, which was razed during the rebellion against the theocracy of the Order of the Eternal Light. Gorgeous plantlife from distant lands is cultivated here, while the beautiful small meadows are open for picnics, and little hidden retreats with benches offer secluded havens for introspection. There is also a perfect view over the Royal Palace from hanging balconies by the Old Wall.

Ruins of the Cathedral of the Sun.name: Ruins of the Cathedral of the Sun
Ruins of the Cathedral of the Sun.text:
The place of worship of the Shining Light, raised more than nine hundred years ago during the theocracy of the Order of the Eternal Light, stands long abandoned. The vaguely recognizable structure of the ruin speaks of the imposing architecture it once displayed. The few waist-high walls that remain are only fragments of the original architecture, which once spread all over the western half of the southern section of the High District from the Angel’s Choir to the Gentlemen’s Refuge.

There is a royal decree in effect, forbidding any excavations in the ruins, which have been maintained in their original forms as a memento of the ancient history of the realm.

Weeping Kobold Fountain.name: Weeping Kobold Fountain
Weeping Kobold Fountain.text:
The monument dominating the area opposite the Eyrie of the Fabled was erected to commemorate Skerg Nethercrest, renowned Court Jester and confidante of Queen Linolu the Peaceful.

The statue depicts a weeping kobold dressed in a jester’s robe. The statue is repainted in bright colors every year. The lost notes of the song Skerg sang to the queen and which secured his role at the court have been sought after by many of the bards of the realm, but none have yet been able to find them.

Gentlemen's Refuge.name: Gentlemen's Refuge
Gentlemen's Refuge.text:
More of a gentleman’s club than a drinking establishment, this tavern features everything from games to comfortable sofas and expensive drinks to accommodate the male elite of the capital.

Access is granted only to those invited by a member and upon payment of the steep annual membership fee of the establishment.

Eyrie of the Fabled.name: Eyrie of the Fabled
Eyrie of the Fabled.text:
The Eyrie of the Fabled is a theater where the nobility and wealthy can meet to enjoy high-quality entertainment and show off their social status.

It is a small yet richly decorated venue built to fulfill every need of visitors from high society.

The theater’s auditorium and stage area is covered with darkwood, making it completely soundproof.

Reference:

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.KmvjlXzSSBi3KCho.JournalEntryPage.VXLZTu957gLnzAwa#eyrie-of-the-fabled]{Eyrie of the Fabled} (Main quest, chapter 3)

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.Pzj3w0T2YNOcOlDq]{Eyrie of the Fabled} (Detailed location information, shadowplane)

  • @UUID[Scene.E5EFFMNhem2DYpKa]{Eyrie of the Fabled} (Map of the Eyrie on the shadowplane, chapter 3)

The Deep Warrens.name: The Deep Warrens
The Deep Warrens.text:
Formed out of an abandoned and partially collapsed segment of the sewers, this tavern is run by a group of ex-convicts who turned away from a life of crime.

One is Schofire the Vengeful, a friendly ex-pirate from Ronul’s End. The next of the gang is Chancebdunn, a tiefling and a professional card player. The third member of the crew is Brak, an arrogant lizardfolk prize hunter, who regretfully reminisces of days before when he drowned wizards in the Ulden Swamps. They take care not to do anything who could ruin their reputation in the eyes of the Red Cloaks.

Chancebdunn is actally a Satyr.

A regular at the tavern, Cassius the Helpful, is a human with a devilish bloodline and a flamboyant outfit who sells information to those who pay the right price. The tavern staff is not fond of his private business here but look away for now.

The deepest domed cellar of the tavern hides the remains of an ancient stone door with a sun symbol on it. The massive stone block is jammed beyond repair under a dilapidated lintel that no one has dared to force open. Beyond the door is a small room where the resistance of slaves and followers of the Shining Light gathered in secret during the reign of the Dark Star. A crumbling skeleton lies in one of the corners, still holding onto a holy symbol in one hand and with the other to a magical spear of solid adamantine that pierced through his body and the stone floor below it.

Reference:

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.PldFtmYx15BRagkN.JournalEntryPage.C5tAJjrsRKymhAU8#writings-on-the-wall]{Writings on the Wall} (Introductory adventure)

Alley of Menace.name: Alley of Menace
Alley of Menace.text:
This alley by the Old Wall is believed to be cursed. Residents avoid it, and those who live next to it urge others to stay away. At any time, day or night, accidents happen to those who enter this relatively simple, dirty, narrow street section that runs between the back walls of several residential buildings.

The markings on the side of the Old Wall in this alley are haunted by the souls of the slaves who built it. Their sorrow and agony emanate through their ancient sigils.

Reference:

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.PldFtmYx15BRagkN.JournalEntryPage.5Gt0b2U2GOdeonxt#rules-are-rules]{Rules Are Rules} (Introductory adventure)

Main Sewer Outlet.name: Main Sewer Outlet
Main Sewer Outlet.text:
This nondescript building is the main entrance to the sewer system of Onadbyr, which runs under the entire city. It consists of many sublevels, the bottom of wich leads to the Primary Drainage Cistern, where waste disposal is regulmated to avoid clogging. The building is usually busy with sewer workers coming and going, and is always guarded by several Royal Swords.

Shrine of the Unforgiving

This secret shrine is at the end of a sewer tunnel below the city’s streets. A composite idol that features the god of death, the god of Strength, and the god of Competence as a three-headed figure stands in a small dark alcove. The statue is usually covered in blood and surrounded by sacrifices left by those who have learned of the place and seek revenge, harbor hate or murderous thoughts, or are under extreme traumatic pressure which they hope to remedy by praying at this isolated shrine. No one knows who or if anyone at all oversees the unholy shrine, but dark candles burn at all times at the feet of the idol.

King Boldizzar Azennar's Statue.name: King Boldizzar Azennar's Statue
King Boldizzar Azennar's Statue.text: Standing on a granite pedestal, this giant iron statue rises above Dragon Plaza and depicts the late @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.xlCqGIMNmyhjubvz#the-azennar-dynasty-(year-354–631)]{King Boldizzar} in the moment of his victory against the invading Vordani armies.

Queen's Grace Orphanage.name: Queen's Grace Orphanage
Queen's Grace Orphanage.text:
This large red brick building with elaborate ironwork is a highly regarded school and residence for young female orphans. Because of royal patronage, conditions in the orphanage are better than in most homes. The girls are raised very rigidly but in a noble demeanor and are trained by the drow headmistress Nyx Malari in all the trades and duties of a lady who is to become a master of a wealthy household. The orphans are well regarded as suitable matches for younger sons of the well-to-do or even for the nobility on rare occasions. The orphans don’t have dowries, estates, or family alliances, but they prepared on posture, courtly dances, running a household, raising children, and many financial tasks.

Lady Nyx utilizes the contacts these married girls represent and keeps close contact with them after they leave the orphanage through frequent visits. Some select girls are members of the @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.iiOhibBiYRG3FzPK#the-ringmaidens]{Ringmaidens}, an organization of underground operatives whom Nix Malari leads in clandestine operations.

The headmistress’s right hand and lead agent is Silent Shadow, a curious catfolk rogue with extraordinary burglary skills. The catfolk has proven able to retrieve anything at the Ringmaiden’s request.

Blackhorn.name: Blackhorn
Blackhorn.text:
Owned by the Blackhorn family for generations, this is one of the oldest taverns in the Onadbyr. The family brews and sells its signature mead that is famous all over the kingdom. The Blackhorns have great pride in the recipe and are in a fierce competition with the monks of the Spirited Leaf Abbey.

The tavern is frequented mainly by locals from the Sword and South Districts.

Temple of Strength.name: Temple of Strength
Temple of Strength.text:
A large, sturdy, and featureless building with small windows dominates the side of the Long Road. Its massive double doors open into a vast training ground, an atrium decorated with weapons and large marble statues of the church’s most famous muscular male and female priests. The most charismatic and approachable priest of the clergy is Casimer, an ambitious half-elf with a wellbuilt physique who capitalizes his knowledge of the body not only in training and keeping a healthy lifestyle but also when using his healing magic.

Reference:

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.RvZvrek5H1zHmg1M#strength]{The Relentless}, god of Strength (Religion of the kingdom)

Meat Market.name: Meat Market
Meat Market.text: The butcher’s market sells all types of meat, live domesticated and wild animals, and sometimes even the remains or live specimens of fantastic beasts brought in by monster hunters.

The Dog Pit.name: The Dog Pit
The Dog Pit.text:
The Dog Pit is an arena of sophisticated duels to the first blood. The place is overseen by a halfling named Joffer Pebblefoot, who don't seems particularly interested in those duels.
The arena is closed at night, to the chagrin of the patrons.

At night, the arena hosts illegal blood sports without any rules at night, where anyone can fight and win some money if they are victorious. Joffer reveals it's true psychopathic nature, and show his love for the sight of blood and gore even more than the gold he makes on his gruesome night business. During the night, the arena seems to be closed, and only those invited can attend the matches, which are kept under wrap by magical silence effects.

So far, the Red Cloaks have not discovered the night-time business.

The real brains of the operation is Joffer’s silent partner Ruali Oussearaheal, a reserved crafty elven rogue with sudden blazes of anger against her rivals.

Reference:

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.GUVYl3sAqhC1ZZtI.JournalEntryPage.PtQ1De0pxWx2P92B]{Battle of Champions} (Part of the main quest)

Enimbros the Rat Catcher.name: Enimbros the Rat Catcher
Enimbros the Rat Catcher.text:
If anyone has a serious rodent infestation, Enimbros the Rat Catcher is the one to find. He is a drow druid who lives on the fringes of society in the Shanties and makes a living by providing pest and rodent control services to anyone who knows about him. He keeps a dozen ferrets in his shabby hovel, which reeks of animal musk and filth.

Enimbros is actually Varrik the Weary, a human druid, who poses as a drow in remembrance of his longlost drow love.

Maggot's End.name: Maggot's End
Maggot's End.text:
This building is home to many miserable wretches who live on drugs and have already forgotten what real life is. Anyone can enter and stay indefinitely if they can find a small spot where they can collapse. The house and its residents are not even worth robbing as they are poor, sick, and without any value to anyone.

The only person taking care of the destitute addicts is Dromier Cutter, a middle-aged priest of the @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.RvZvrek5H1zHmg1M#life]{Redeemer} who appears to be in his fifties. Dromier’s mean demeanor and harsh temperament hides a caring soul who preaches to the homeless of Maggot’s End about changing their ways before distributing alms to them.

Fiery Hooves.name: Fiery Hooves
Fiery Hooves.text:
The little shop is tucked into the cramped space of the city’s outskirts, close to Mule Gate. Its entrance is marked by a metal cut-out sign depicting a rider and a horse with flaming hooves. The shop is known by its customers for its high-quality harnesses, saddles, leather gear, and other equipment, which seem to be highly durable but at the same time light in weight. Rumor has it that the saddler, Mordio Delons keeps a little dragon-like creature in his workshop to harden the materials.

The shop’s interior is designed to block the view of the workbench for a good reason. The truth is that Mordio is the head of the Children of the Coven, malicious servitors of the Matrons of Malice. He received an imp servant as payment for his devotion, and besides for spying, he also uses the tiny fiend to work for him on tasks that require great precision.

Reference:

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.GUVYl3sAqhC1ZZtI.JournalEntryPage.0yhia5MysY9IUZ0K#fake-robbery]{Fake Robbery} (Criminal activity during the King's games, chapter 1)

Green-Eyed Nymph.name: Green-Eyed Nymph
Green-Eyed Nymph.text: Only green-eyed servers work at this large festhall facing the Dragon Plaza. The hall features regular group dances for locals and is frequented by many of the students of the College of Minstrels, who always make sure to keep the guests and themselves entertained at all times of the day.

Temple of Magic.name: Temple of Magic
Temple of Magic.text:
Marvelous colorful, sparking columns of heatless fire dominate the entrance of this temple, which is rich in detail. Its large rose glass windows seem to shift as shapes form and disappear in them slowly. The inside of the building features magical enchantments and imagery, which always awes visitors and faithful alike.

The priests of the House of the @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.RvZvrek5H1zHmg1M#magic]{Wondermaker} welcome all who are fascinated by their god’s power and those who wish to hire their magical services. These services are usually provided by Wilm the Virtuous, an aged, stolid human priest who is all too pragmatic about the magical wonders he sells. The highest-ranking cleric of the temple is a venerable human named Polodrin of Gynleah, a foreigner from the @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.YBau4aklzXO4754W#drayl-city-states]{Drayl City-States}, who was invited by King Waldrann decades ago to take the Pulpit of Wonders. His second in command is Father Beau Semias, who is a charismatic pastor.

Beau, puts on a mask of deception, as he is a scheming devotee of the Matrons of Malice. Father Beau vies for power, and the midnight hags easily corrupted him by offering magical powers that he could use to overthrow Father Polodrin.

With his newfound warlock powers, the vile priest already has a plan in motion and regularly reports to Mordio Delons, the cult’s leader.

Reference:

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.RvZvrek5H1zHmg1M#magic]{The Wondermaker}, god of Magic (Religion of the kingdom)

Basket of Plenty.name: Basket of Plenty
Basket of Plenty.text: The primary food market of the capital is a vast sea of colors and sounds filled with an ever-flowing mass of people and a full range of enticing aromas. One can buy almost any type of food, even from far-off exotic lands, except for meat, which is only available at the @UUID[.79g2MBivmGJcMoz5]{Meat Market} (location 102). Long rows of tiny curtained stalls, most with only seats for two customers, line the sides of the market where one can find any type of street food at all hours of the day.

Ratcatcher Inn.name: Ratcatcher Inn
Ratcatcher Inn.text:
The Ratcatcher is the worst place to stay at Onadbyr but also the cheapest. The proprietor, Gibras the Meek, is a silent introvert with dark sunken eyes and an air of eerie strangeness about his person.

The loudest regulars at the place are always Fingle Jewelstomper, a bearded chubby gnome rogue with wizardly skills who asks way too many questions, and his friend Keeg, a charismatic, carefree con-artist and steady drinker who claims to be an ex-pirate captain of the west.

Dragon Plaza.name: Dragon Plaza
Dragon Plaza.text:
Formerly known as the Plaza of the People, this enormous empty plaza is dominated by the bronze statue of @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.xlCqGIMNmyhjubvz#the-azennar-dynasty-(year-354–631)]{King Daerios Azennar}, the current king’s father. He defeated and chased away Malzdreziret the Scaled Impostor.

The statue depicts the heroic king as he wounds the massive dragon with the Falcon Blade.

Reference:

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.GUVYl3sAqhC1ZZtI.JournalEntryPage.ZOPkaJIb1KcUOw1k#battle-of-the-tipsy-tunes]{Battle of the Tipsy Tunes} (Competition during the King's games, chapter 1)

Music of the Spheres.name: Music of the Spheres
Music of the Spheres.text: The venerable gnome instrument maker Master Xagim Doubletoe undoubtedly has the most refined ears and most skilled hands in the capital. Most of the students and maestros of the @UUID[.76KqRw9Y32UCdzY1]{College of Minstrels} (location 25) have their instruments made and repaired by him. Even though he has slowly gone deaf, he can still tune any instrument perfectly by feeling its vibrations.

The Bottomless Well.name: The Bottomless Well
The Bottomless Well.text:
This ancient, crumbling well looks like any other old neglected well, except for the fact that no one has ever been able to reach its bottom. Lanterns on ropes of extreme length have been lowered into it until the light just slowly faded away. The brave who have tried to climb or even fly down with magic either gave up or never returned. Inside there’s a long stretch of ladders and handholds fabricated together and added continuously by those who dared to explore, but at one point, it just stops, marking the depth where the last brave explorer gave up the descent.

Legends say that a few times in the past, the corpses of strange creatures, possibly fey, have mysteriously fallen out of the well.

The well is an interplanar tunnel between the Prime Materialplane and Faery. But the only means of traversing is falling through, wich take one full year. Without means of sustenance, any falling creature is doomed to die.

Mug and Bottle.name: Mug and Bottle
Mug and Bottle.text:
A goodhearted middle-aged dwarf named Guunthar runs this fine brewery. He has a rotund cat named Pudge and a pet skunk that believes itself to be a cat, named Stinky.

Unfortunately, Guunthar has a sad history with a red dragon. Guunthar was a highly skilled armorsmith and adventurer back in the days before briefly meeting Arzatraxos, the red dragon in Drayl, then promptly changing his profession and life goals.

Roundbread.name: Roundbread
Roundbread.text: The Roundbread bakery is an institution by itself. Long lines of hungry shoppers wait for their turn in front of its doors every morning. People would do anything for Gallad, the stern-looking but kind airling master baker, who is a renowned and respected pillar of the community

Old Pharion's Remedies.name: Old Pharion's Remedies
Old Pharion's Remedies.text:
Jamos Pharion is the sweetest old man, always talkative, and very helpful, especially when offering his herbal remedies primarily to other elderly residents.

He also sells several plant-based poisons from his small shop to those who know his secret signal.

Jamos’ most valued treasure is an ancient adamantine mace that once belonged to one of the fallen devas during the reign of the Dark Star.

Aunty Alania's Sewing Shop.name: Aunty Alania's Sewing Shop
Aunty Alania's Sewing Shop.text: Aunty Alania was the wife of a wealthy merchant who died decades ago. She has spent her entire life sewing since she was a child and she makes the most beautiful and fashionable dresses worn by the nobility and elite of the city.

Sylvan Striker, Bows of Elven Quality.name: Sylvan Striker, Bows of Elven Quality
Sylvan Striker, Bows of Elven Quality.text:
Twen Foebane came to the city from an elven conclave in Drayl to forget a tragic romantic affair. He has watched the city grow for over a century now and established a name for himself as one of the capital’s most skilled craftsmen. Twen is always accompanied by his animal companion, a loyal dog named Kylo.

Reference:

@UUID[JournalEntry.GUVYl3sAqhC1ZZtI.JournalEntryPage.ZOPkaJIb1KcUOw1k#the-nimble-eagle]{The Nimble Eagle} (Part of the main quest, optional event during the King's games)

Galnyr, Master Armorer.name: Galnyr, Master Armorer
Galnyr, Master Armorer.text:
Galnyr was a member of a Vordani tribe until he realized that his armor-crafting skills are valued much more in Aglarion and the capital of Onadbyr.

The seasoned blacksmith has created many masterpieces worn with pride by their owners.

Figurines of Wonder.name: Figurines of Wonder
Figurines of Wonder.text:
Vilter Kirtan, a middle-aged human maker of fine dolls and puppets, creates wonderful toys and dolls of various sizes to the delight of young and old alike. The puppet maker lost his wife and daughter, Dorotia, to a long and severe illness a few years ago.

He was soon confronted by the Matrons of Malice in his dreams. He was told that if he recreated Dorotia as a puppet, it would gain sentience and eternal life so he could love her forever. The heartbroken master crafter accepted the offer without hesitation and soon finished the doll. It was as promised, and during the next night, the doll came to life and has been by Vilter’s side ever since. The puppet maker hides the secret of his live puppet from everyone, but it is always with him in the shop during the day, falling prone and acting lifeless if anyone enters. The puppet was initially kind and loving, but it grows viler over time as her haglike personality starts to surface, changing her appearance bit by bit.

Zurafkira's Fine Footwear.name: Zurafkira's Fine Footwear
Zurafkira's Fine Footwear.text:
This small cordwainer’s workshop is the shop and home of Zurafkira Shoemaker, a single woman of great skill.

Zurafkira has a mysterious connection to the Shadowrealm. She has a twin sister born to the Shadowrealm when their mother gave life to them and died in the process.

The Shadowrealm-born Zurafkira is a skillful survivor who manages on her own within the desolate world of shadows. At the same time, the Material Plane Zurafkira became a skillful cobbler who always tried to help her slightly bitter sister with information and advice.

The two sisters can see and communicate telepathically with each other when they both look into a mirror.

The sisters became informants, and direct proteges of Samsadur after the leader of the Golden Masks found out about their secret.

The girls enjoy the company of the crime lord, the excitement he brings to their lives with his missions of reconnaissance, and the gold pieces he pays them.

Temple of Life.name: Temple of Life
Temple of Life.text:
The Temple of the Redeemer is a sprawling lowceilinged building with large communal areas and a central pulpit. The temple can accommodate hundreds of people, and many clerics attend the hungry, wounded, sick, and destitute. Anyone can stay at the temple for free for an indefinite time, provided they assist in the daily labors of the acolyte clerics. The ranking cleric of the faith is @UUID[Actor.PWr8rF052RkFfMas]{Ry Kaly} who does his best to attend the most severe cases.

Ry Kaly is a low-level priest

The most dedicated and active member of the clergy is Otmer Honormail, an unarmored, unarmed dwarven paladin who tends to every need of the disenfranchised in his simple dirty robes.

References:

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.RvZvrek5H1zHmg1M#life]{The Redeemer}, god of Life (Religion of the kingdom)

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.PldFtmYx15BRagkN.JournalEntryPage.5Gt0b2U2GOdeonxt#wicked-witchery]{Wicked Witchery} (Introductory adventure)

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.gS49Y4V8ndlWc4Yp.JournalEntryPage.2e1zr4d5ImRusklC#temple-of-life]{Temple of Life} (Onadbyr, City of the Dead, chapter 6)

Knight's Pride.name: Knight's Pride
Knight's Pride.text: This large weapon and armor smithy is run by a massive hobgoblin named Bruukattyr the Iron Grip, who served in the Royal Army for years. He received an honorable discharge after losing his left hand in a battle against a mob of sahuagin that attacked Ronul’s End over two decades ago. As a result, he constructed a bulky iron left arm prosthesis for himself that has a tremendous grip but is too bulky to be used for anything else but swinging a hammer.

Nine Arches.name: Nine Arches
Nine Arches.text:
This flat bridge is built upon nine stone arches. The bridge was destroyed by Malzdreziret the Scaled Impostor, before being rebuilt only a decade ago by King Waldrann.

Newlywed couples often take rowboats and navigate to one of the many bridge pillars to carve their names there.

References:

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.GUVYl3sAqhC1ZZtI.JournalEntryPage.qvV6PyPkRP6i9tTv#the-treasure-tree]{The Treasure Tree} (Malicious treasure hunt event during the King's games, chapter 1)

Diamondback Trout.name: Diamondback Trout
Diamondback Trout.text: This cozy tavern by the riverside features its own small docks and canopied terraces over the river. The owner, Okamirou Haristan, is a knowledgeable man from a distant land to the east and a long-time friend of King Waldrann.

Nulobor's Fine Locks.name: Nulobor's Fine Locks
Nulobor's Fine Locks.text:
Nulobor, the gnome, is an introvert who does nothing besides making and repairing locks and eating his favorite lemon pie strictly at sundown in his favorite chair overlooking his small fireplace.

He keeps adding drops of the essential oils he buys from Old Troumbald of @UUID[.UXkMQDbkjLkEGqsC]{Natural Healing Concoctions} (Onadbyr location 46) to his fire, which should supposedly ease his frequent headaches.

He works most of the time and sometimes has strange, suffocating dreams in which ugly deformed women sit on his chest and hold a glowing bag over his mouth.

Ronnar's Pelts and Fine Leather.name: Ronnar's Pelts and Fine Leather
Ronnar's Pelts and Fine Leather.text:
Ronnar, a middle-aged half-orc, buys, cures, and sells the most exotic pelts and hides from all over the kingdom. He also sometimes deceives some of his wealthier clients with expert forgeries.

Ronnar’s best supplier is an elven druid named Theduthas Ravine, who uses his powers to find beasts with pelts of the highest quality in the King’s Forest, where he hunts illegally

Temple of Competence.name: Temple of Competence
Temple of Competence.text:
An unremarkable-looking two-story building in the middle of the densest part of the Tool District is home to the devotees of the god of @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.RvZvrek5H1zHmg1M#competence]{Competence}, the Efficient Master. The temple hides many small workshops where the skilled can discuss their trade or the unskilled can learn confidence in a skill from the temple priests.

There is no formal leader of the faith because all priests consider each other as equals and act as independent teachers and preachers of their own experiences.

One of the friendlier faces in the temple is an acolyte named Jarlin, a former street urchin who found his way into the temple. The introvert boy is a master poet who is willing to share his art with anyone eager to listen.

Jarlin is actually is a young doppelganger named Namacursess. He is a loner and not affiliated with the Golden Masks, who will approach and tempt the creature if they find out its true identity.

Reference:

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.RvZvrek5H1zHmg1M#competence]{The Efficient Master} (God of Competence, religions of the kingdom)

Nail and Beam Carpentry.name: Nail and Beam Carpentry
Nail and Beam Carpentry.text:
Jovas Paltran and his team led by his three sons have built the most magnificent villas over the past years.

They also do major repairs but leave the smaller, less well-paying jobs to others of their profession.

The Wondermonger.name: The Wondermonger
The Wondermonger.text:
This messy workshop, owned by Tully Vespers Skincat Watercat, is only a small room packed with strange devices and another space in the back separated by a curtain. Some might consider the animated clockwork contraptions of the warm-hearted gnome artificer wizard useless or even funny, but many have great functions that make one’s life easier.

Tully is always friendly and curious and does not consider it offensive when people belittle his automatons and clockwork tools.

Tully is actually a werecat in control of his powers who occasionally roams the rooftops of the city at night.

Grinning Goblin.name: Grinning Goblin
Grinning Goblin.text:
Owned and operated by the goblins of the Goldtooth noble house, this tavern is always noisy with shouting and raucous laughter. Constantly guarded by the disciplined and courteous hobgoblin house guards, the locals consider the inn as a safe place to get drunk.

One of the loudest guests is Breesy Alebeard, a smuggler with a purple glass eye and a jade tooth, who is always ready to bet large in a game of cards.

Ronul Villa.name: Ronul Villa
Ronul Villa.text:
The house of the infamous @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.y73fauf7VCxVrzTe#house-ronul]{Ronul} family is one with lots of balconies and open spaces akin to the helm of a ship.

It is said that Almerio Ronul built his house around the mast of his original flagship, and that part of the house is underwater, catering to the few merfolk in the family. Lord Dyzag Ronul, the family’s patriarch, seldom visits since he is kept busy overseeing the pearl fishing in the north bay in Ronul’s end. His only son, Premil Ronul, keeps the house in order and stays here most of the time.

  • The young noble is secretly in love with Odryk Nangrath, the older son of @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.y73fauf7VCxVrzTe#house-nangrath]{House Nangrath}.

  • From time to time, gossip goes around the black markets and rogues of the city that Almerio Ronul had hidden his famed cache of treasure somewhere in the city, and that the clues about its location are hidden inside the house. Lord Dyzag Ronul would tell you that this was only a bad joke that his grandfather made and regretted immediately. Since then, the Ronul family had to pay fortunes to protect the house from burglars and sometimes adventurers who believe the tale.

Reference:

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.y73fauf7VCxVrzTe#house-ronul]{House Ronul} (Noble house)

References.name: References
References.text:
The Midnight Curse

The curse of the Matrons of Malice is activated by the coronation of Queen Aphinah and it rapidly engulfs the entire Kingdom of Aglarion. It is dubbed by those who endure its vile effects the Midnight Curse because of the storm’s nature of raging the most at midnight. The curse affects the lives of everyone within the realm, corrupting and straining living and non-living matter equally. It changes people’s everyday lives and shakes the structures of society in general, as work, travel, and living becomes strenuous and dangerous. The following examples are some of the more rare effects of the curse and represent the extremities of the new circumstances. Use them sparsely from time to time, separately, or combined to demonstrate the effects of the curse.

Cursed Phenomenons

The Midnight Curse is a form of concentrated malignity that aims to worsen the everyday life of the Kingdom of Aglarion. It carries the vile sadism of the Matrons of Malice and it is infused with their magical powers that manifest in various forms. Most of the time these cursed phenomena hit those the hardest who are opposing the core mindset of the hag coven, like cheerful individuals, those who are dedicated to aiding others, or those who are the least vulnerable.

Rise of the Dead

The dead return to life and assault the living. This phenomenon happens usually in the case of loved ones and relatives who not just threaten the lives of those they loved but also cause a terrible trauma to them. The risen undead are usually skeletons, zombies, or ghouls who seek out their families or closely related individuals.

Baleful Transformation

Some of those who would oppose the cruel ideology of the Matrons of Malice find themselves mutated in one form or another. A limb of an athletic person could grow monstrous or weaken, or the beautiful face of a maiden could turn hideous with horrid blisters, pimples, or even grow scales over a night. Those affected must make a [[/save 14 con]] saving throw or gain a disadvantage on either Strength (&Reference[ath]), Dexterity (&Reference[acr]), or Charisma ability and related skill checks depending on the form of the curse. This effect can be ended by the use of a remove curse spell.

Terrifying Nightmares

The midnight hags are masters of nightmares and the Midnight Curse spreads their evil influence over dreams. Anyone affected by these terrifying nightmares has such a restless night that they can’t enjoy the benefits of a long rest and take [[/damage 1d6 psychic average]] damage after waking up from the nightmare.

Weather

Dark purplish, unnatural thick clouds appear all over the realm and the weather turns gloomy, cold, and wet with continuous rain. The rain exhausts, weakens, and eventually kills people if they are exposed to it for too long. The debilitating liquid pours down seemingly endlessly, stopping for only a few hours before continuing with varied intensity until midnight when it rages at its maximum potential. The soil is almost always wet and landslides become more frequent. The occasional purple lightning strikes hit places and people as if knowing where to cause the most damage. Those who survive become cursed, fumbling with their motions and always suffering the worst outcome of a situation. The winds are of constantly changing intensity and seem to play tricks on people. They sometimes intensify to express their will even more obviously, occasionally not ceasing to rage for days.

Choking Rain

The rains of the Everstorm seep into the Material Plane from the Bleak Mire and affect every humanoid creature. A creature affected by the Choking Rain must make a successful [[save con 13]] saving throw every hour of being exposed to the Choking Rain or gain a level of exhaustion. Using makeshift covers or umbrellas offer minor protection, requiring saving throws to be made every two hours. Only a completely waterproof enclosure can protect against the effects of the Choking Rain. The runoff or collected rainwater itself doesn’t convey the same curse effect.

Hex Lightning

A creature hit by Hex Lightning must make a [[/save dex 13]] saving throw. A creature takes [[/damage 8d6 lightning average]] damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. On a failed save the creature must also succeed on a [[/save wis 13]] saving throw or become cursed for one day. While cursed, the creature has disadvantage on ability checks and saving throws. Spells that create a bolt of lightning from storm clouds, like the call lightning spell, also have this additional curse effect on their targets. The Hex Lightning ignites flammable objects that aren't being worn or carried.

Devious Wind

Any medium or smaller creature affected by the harsh blast of wind must make a [[/save str 13]] saving throw. On a failed save the character might fall prone, or drop any items held in one hand, depending on the DM’s discretion.

Vegetation

The Choking Rain and the damp, cold, sunless weather drowns the vegetation less dependent on water while also causing some species to grow and mutate unnaturally. Sometimes these strange mutations in the vegetation become seemingly intelligent or might gain magical properties, and seem to always be hostile to other creatures. The rotting and wet flora is fertile ground for all kinds of mosses, lichen, molds, and fungi.

Bloodletting Thorns

A plant or tree grows sharp, triple-spiked barbs that cause [[/damage 1d6 slashing average]] damage to anyone passing through or climbing on them. A creature taking damage from such Bloodletting Thorns loses 1 hit point per round from bleeding that doesn’t stop naturally. A successful [[/check med 14]] skill check, or a spell that causes the character to regain hit points, stops the bleeding.

Stranglevine

A plant or tree grows several 10 feet or longer vines that are as thick as a rope. As an action, the Stranglevine entangles any creature that comes into its reach. The target creature must succeed on a [[/save str 13]] saving throw or be &Reference[restrained]{restrained} by the Stranglevine. As an action the Stranglevine can attempt to choke a restrained creature. The restrained target creature must succeed on a [[/save str 13]] saving throw or start &Reference[suffocating]{choking}. The restrained or choked creature can use its action to break free by succeeding on a [[/save str 13]]saving throw. An average stranglevine has AC 10, 12 hit points.

Braintainter Fungi.

This pinkish tubular fungus grows on any dump surface in patches or even in larger colonies. The Braintainter emits a poisonous spore from its chimney-like body whenever a creature approaches it within 5 feet. The spore cloud spreads in a 5 foot radius around the mushroom and the Braintainter fungus becomes inactive for 24 hours. A creature that inhales the spores of the Braintainter must succeed on a [[/save int 13]] saving throw. On a failed save the creature must roll a d6 each time they make an Intelligence or Wisdom ability check or saving throw, and subtract the number rolled from the result. The effect ends after the target creature takes a long rest.

Fauna

Most of the wildlife is affected by the Midnight Curse through the changes in natural habitats and the scarcity of available nutritious resources. Beasts and wildlife are hungry and distressed, often relentlessly seeking food wherever they can. Predators attack smaller creatures on sight, they wander longer distances, and are often sick with infections or even mutated with ferocious bone spurs extruding from their mouths and claws. The bodies of weakened and eventually deceased animals litter the wilderness.

Spasmodic Rabies

This brain infection causes uncontrollable spasms in the body of the infected creature. A beast or humanoid in physical contact with a diseased creature must succeed on a [[/save con 13]] saving throw or become infected. On a failed save, the infected creature gains disadvantage on ability checks, attack rolls, and saving throws. At the end of each long rest, an infected creature must make a [[/save con 13]] saving throw. On a failed save, the character remains infected. On a successful save, the creature recovers from the infection.

Bone Augmentations

The beast or monstrosity grows additional teeth and fangs, or the original ones become larger, turning it into a disfigured, vicious-looking version of its original form. The damage die of the natural weapons of the creature increases by one die type.

Vile Intellect

The beast or monstrosity gains an unnaturally evil intellect, more cunningly pursuing its goals that are different than those of its original kind. It can evaluate cause and effect relationships and operate simple mechanisms. The Intelligence ability score of the creature changes to 6 and it doesn’t speak but understands Common.

Werehellhound Lycanthropy

The rules for lycanthropy apply to the curse of werehellhound lycanthropy as outlined in the Lycanthropes section of the Monster Manual and the @UUID[JournalEntry.PAvJUI93js934tpB.JournalEntryPage.BZ83hCDcrVRCxJNH]{werehellhound monster template} included in @UUID[JournalEntry.PAvJUI93js934tpB]{Appendix D: NPCs and Monsters}. The curse of werehellhound lycanthropy is spread solely through the bite of afflicted werehellhounds. From time to time, the werehellhound knights of Queen Aphinah leave wounded victims only to cause suffering through their curse. News of afflicted individuals and their senseless rampages of fire spreads faster in the realm than the lycanthropic curse itself, to the utmost delight of the Queen. As a result, most households try to acquire some silver weapons and store large barrels of water, never leaving home on the night of a full moon.

The Kingdom of Aglarion

It only takes the Midnight Curse a few weeks to drastically and dramatically change the lives of all creatures in the Kingdom of Aglarion. Everyday life has become strenuous and dangerous, turning almost every day for most into a struggle for survival. Nature has mutated and turned against everything that lives. The radical changes in ordinary life, the scarcity in food and resources, and the loss of comfort and safety have all had drastic effects on both the land and the creatures who live in it. All of the magical effects and unprecedented occurrences are constrained to the territory of the Kingdom of Aglarion, making every other place outside the kingdom a desired destination for those who can reach them.

See @UUID[JournalEntry.Nq3FpTKjZRMBlD6Z]{Cursed Kingdom of Aglarion: points of Interests} (Chapter 4.) for detailed description of changes at different encounter locations throughout the kingdom.

Onadbyr

After a couple of days under the effects of the Midnight Curse, Onadbyr becomes a dirty, gloomy, and dangerous place. The streets are almost empty most of the day and totally abandoned at night, especially during the choking rain. People hurry to reach their destinations and only venture onto the streets when absolutely necessary. The taverns and inns of the city stand empty most of the time and get-togethers are curtailed. The city reeks of death and chaos, the orderliness of the past is gone and it is replaced with the unknown and the unexpectable. The oppression of Queen Aphinah is tangible in every aspect of life. Her focus on causing distress and suffering, her sadistic and cruel ways, and her negligence towards the population, or towards anything in her kingdom in general, has all shown its marks on the city, which slowly crumbles to pieces.

Economy

Most shops continue to stay open in Aglarion, but all businesses struggle with the lack of resources and clients. Prices have tripled but people hoard goods out of necessity. As a result, shelves stand empty, showing only a fraction of the previous stock they had before the Midnight Curse. Most services are also interrupted, especially establishments of entertainment and hospitality as everyone stays indoors and avoids get-togethers. Inns and taverns are empty, except for the few regulars who would in any case spend their days there.

Agriculture and animal husbandry come to a standstill, as grazing becomes impossible and fields are inundated by the cursed rains. Surviving animals are moved into barns and only greenhouses can provide the meagre amount of produce to feed the populace. The result is famine and disease.

Existing taxes are increased and new taxes are instituted by the freshly crowned Queen Aphinah, some of them outlandish in nature, and often changing daily at the whim of the Queen. The Royal Army is tasked with tax collection and collecting the fines that result from confusing edicts that cannot be followed, sometimes not even by the tax collectors.

Gold coins bearing the visage of King Waldrann and recalled and impounded without recompense if not deposited for melting at the King’s Forge, which mints new gold pieces with the countenance of Queen Aphinah.

Social structure

There is a great upheaval in the social fabric of the realm with the curse and the new power structure. Everything becomes centralized to the Royal Palace, which becomes the seat of ultimate authority in the realm. Guilds, clergy, and nobles are all stripped of their responsibilities and related incomes as regiments of Royal Swords become the undertakers of all tasks related to commerce and infrastructure, mostly tax collection and enforcement in a centralized and militaristic fashion. Social programs are suspended as the Royal Palace abandons its charity work. Closeness to the new court becomes the primary arbitrator of status and graces are given depending on the fickle whim of Queens Aphinah, which is chaotic, random, and malicious.

Laws

Among the first edicts of Queen Aphinah, after her interdict on the Knight of the Crown and the clergies, is the disbanding of the Court of Voices and the centralization of the judiciary in her royal personage. Queen Aphinah makes a number of new decrees, which are often quite personal and usually arbitrary in nature, attest to the malign and childish nature of the queen. For example the court outlaws and impounds all perfumes, while Aphinah douses herself with the choicest fragrances.

A vast web of informants is overseen by Blister, through Mordio Delons, the leader of the Children of the Coven. They seek out all sparks of resistance threats to the crown and offer targets to the authorities to be apprehended or executed by Royal Swords, Red Cloaks, or the werehellhound knights of the Queen. This network breeds corruption and injustice, as hordes of innocent people are eliminated on the word of others for deeds they did not commit.

The Royal Swords and Red Cloak Lawgivers still enforce the new laws to the best of their abilities but many have already abandoned their duties and fled. Fines and penalties become more severe and are doubled in general. If the fines cannot be paid, long imprisonment and hard labor become the standard sentences. The Dungeon of Tears and the Sobruz Penitentiary are filled to the brim, as more and more “deviants” are cramped into small cells. In cases of treason and blasphemy (the use of divine magic), the penalty of execution is always the chosen sentence, and is conducted via public hangings on the spot around the city.

Citizens

Masses of people abandon their homes and livelihoods as they desperately brave the treacherous trip to escape Aglarion to the southern Drayl City States or take to the open seas and head for the mythical and remote Isles of Xantharos in the hopes of reaching the legendary isles. The roads are scattered with migrants, pitifully lugging their few precious belongings and often abandoning them when they cannot carry them further from sheer exhaustion. Many perish on the way, their bodies rotting in the rain on the sides of the roads, which are no longer maintained by the Royal Swords.

Nobles

The noble houses of Aglarion all react differently to the new regime of Queen Aphinah and the effects of the Midnight Curse. There are those who oppose the edits of the Queen, especially those that relate to the forcible acquisition of their property and resources by the crown, there are those that remain neutral and acquiesce to the demands of the crown, and those that seek opportunity and status by becoming loyalists of the new Queen.

@UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.y73fauf7VCxVrzTe#house-monder]{House Monder} is stripped of its noble title and unfortunately the line of the Monders ends with the demise of Crownwarden Lord Cyne Monder.

After refusing the Royal Swords that have been sent to @UUID[JournalEntry.bhFFbrHi0j5J8Xgg.JournalEntryPage.dNqwT8nzl4eGWMZj]{Ronul’s End} by Queen Aphinah, the village is razed by Whoshinassh the sea hag who jumps at the occasion to fulfill its revenge, reinforced by a company of werehellhounds sent by Blister as a token of an alliance with the sea hag. The village lies in flames, the Boundless Pearl is reduced to ashes, and the slain bodies of the villagers and merforlk, float rotting in the bay.

The members of @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.y73fauf7VCxVrzTe#house-nangrath]{House Nangrath} regroup in their northern fort and fortify the town, ready to resist the crown from their distant location, however an ill fate befalls the house, which is plagued by calamities on two fronts. Gargoyles from Fort Blackbell have been raiding the town during the day, kidnapping victims to grow their brood, while Bakator and his duergar vampires seize the opportunity to rise to the surface under the cover of the night from Darkstone and feed on the blood of the town and steal its riches. They have killed Arenbar Nangrath and his eldest heir Yarik, and kidnapped Odryk, who has returned to his ancestral home from Onadbyr.

Houses @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.y73fauf7VCxVrzTe#house-karramosa]{Karramosa}, @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.y73fauf7VCxVrzTe#house-domiren]{Domiren}, @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.y73fauf7VCxVrzTe#house-goldtooth]{Goldtooth}, and @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.y73fauf7VCxVrzTe#house-wyltammer]{Wyltammer} decide to play a waiting game, retreating to their mansion in Onadbyr and manors around the kingdom, opting to stay neutral in the troubled times. The quest of the Wyltammers for eternal life is interrupted and the family grows anxious with the new regime, their source of life essence at their famous balls in jeopardy due to the curse. Yram and Taya are forced to seek alternative sources for life essence, mainly through Taya’s warlock abilities, the purchase of slaves from @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.YBau4aklzXO4754W#isles-of-xantharos]{Xantharos}, or Yram’s connections in the city like the @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.iiOhibBiYRG3FzPK#black-flag-mercenary-company]{Black Flags mercenary} company.

@UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.y73fauf7VCxVrzTe#house-gorso]{House Gorso} immediately swears allegiance to Queen Aphinah and is the foremost loyalist in the new political scene. However, the house is careful to maintain its independence and withdraws to Gorso village. They revel in the newspawned chaos from afar, seeing portents for the coming of their patron, the Elemental Chaos.

Knights of the Crown

The schism that has resulted in Queen Aphinah’s ascendance to the throne has split the sacred order in half. Only a dozen knights have survived on the side of Lord Cyne Monder, who have held onto their oaths to serve the kingdom and to protect it from threats. They view that some malignant effect has corrupted the crown and that Queen Aphinah is no longer deserving of their protection. On the other side, most of the @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.iiOhibBiYRG3FzPK#knights-of-the-crown]{Knight of the Crown} interpreted their vows in the most literal sense and have as a result become werehellhound knights who maintain their oaths to protect the sovereign above all.

Royal Army

The ranks of the Royal Swords swells as a result of the chaos of the new reign, as the army is singular in offering daily fare and some semblance of stability in these times of famine and uncertainty. While many flock to the army, most are barely trained and have never held a weapon. The new recruits are used for menial tasks, like digging ditches, clearing rubble and in overseeing the transport of goods that are reserved for the Royal Treasury.

Red Cloaks

The @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.iiOhibBiYRG3FzPK#red-cloak-lawgivers]{Red Cloaks} struggle to maintain some semblance of order in the realm and work to enforce the new edicts of Queen Aphinah that grow more and more haphazard and cruel as the days and weeks pass. Many Red Cloaks abandon the organization and their official posts to fend for themselves and brave the trip to the borders.

Criminals

The chaos and lax oversight by the authorities is a boon to petty crime in the city, where many try to survive and get ahead in the drastic times to the detriment and suffering of their peers. Burglaries, armed robberies, and muggings are more frequent but are still controlled to some degree by the Royal Swords and the remaining Red Cloaks.

The Midnight Curse is a huge blow to the criminal organizations of the city, the @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.iiOhibBiYRG3FzPK#golden-masks]{Golden Masks} and the @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.iiOhibBiYRG3FzPK#uncanny-vagabonds]{Uncanny Vagabonds}, who are both severely hampered by the detrimental effects of the cursed rain on the economy in general and their operations in turn. The Golden Masks seek to exploit the new circumstances and remain underground, while the Uncanny Vagabonds flee to the city from their caravans in hopes of better chances of survival. Taris, the leader of the family, is also weighing how to best exploit the situation, biding his time to best serve the family’s interests.

Temples

All temples of Aglarion are immediately raided by the Queen’s Royal Swords and werehellhound knights and officially closed by the authorities. All clerics on the premises are slaughtered and those that escape the carnage are hunted down by the @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.iiOhibBiYRG3FzPK#children-of-the-coven]{Children of the Coven} and then persecuted by the werehellhound commandos of the Queen. Anyone who uses divine magic is circumspect and unfortunately the agents of the Queen and Blister comprise a vast network of informants. Clerics of all faiths who were not present at the coronation and were not rooted out in the flash raids on all the temples in the city are in hiding, surviving by the grace of those who help them remain out of the clutches of the new regime. The sole exception is Beau Semias, a priest of the @UUID[JournalEntry.unUwzkbA5fQamYlH.JournalEntryPage.gjVSfd02ms595OWg]{Temple of Magic} (Onadbyr location 108.) and a warlock servitor of the hags who murders his superior and relishes in his new found status within the cult of the Children of the Coven.

Neighbors

Trade and diplomacy with neighboring states comes to a sudden halt. Foreign merchant caravans from @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.YBau4aklzXO4754W#drayl-city-states]{Drayl} to the south or @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.YBau4aklzXO4754W#vordan]{Vordan} in the north turn back at the borders at the sight of the cursed weather conditions. There is an exodus of ships from Onadbyr and Ronul’s End, fleeing to southern waters or even on desperate voyages to find the legendary @UUID[JournalEntry.mjmyuZYe4n13wv3f.JournalEntryPage.YBau4aklzXO4754W#isles-of-xantharos]{Isles of Xantharos}.

The mass exodus of people from Aglarion also strains the neighboring powers. The Vordan tribes completely close the borders when the refugees start to arrive in floods. The Drayl States are more lax and varied in their approach to the migrants depending on the city, generally seeing great opportunity in the masses of people who are now settling in their lands.

While the Midnight Curse only plagues the Kingdom of Aglarion, many of its effects seep into the surrounding lands. Mutated augmented beasts from the Ulden Forest or the Talnar Hills spread spasmodic rabies into Vordan and Drayl, but the weak and crippled refugees also bring many new, previously not encountered diseases.
